content:
Posted: November 10, 2012
												Bully is a very interesting game by Rockstar. It was clear Rockstar wanted to try something different compared to their uber violent and masochistic GTA/Manhunt franchises. So they created Bully, which is in essance a parody on the mass violence that goes on in their games.In this game you play as a former high school bully, Jimmy Hopkins. Who is a major reference to coming of age protagonists like Holden Caulfield. The plot is actually fairly interesting and has a few nice twists here and there. It molds nicely with the gameplay, which is similar to San Andreas except your weapons are things like slingshots and bottle rockets. The world itself is also unique, as the game goes on seasons change and the world reflects this nicely.Bully is one of my favorite Rockstar games, and it comes highly recommended from me. It is well worth the price of admission.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												The game is pretty funny, I'll give it that. I really liked the rivalry and chemistry between Gary and Jim, though I wish there would be a sequel where Gary returns. The "weapons" are highly creative and enjoyable, and you can even go to classes and pass them after doing various tasks and get good grades. There is a main plotline of course, and "quests" or missions to do in sub-plots while following along the main plot, but like many a high school kid's dream, the end goal is to become the head honcho and live it up with the popularity, as leader of the cliques.Ah, there's also that. Cliques, cliques everywhere! And very cliche too, however being the badass that Jim is, he (you) gets to eventually control all of them and keep them in line. From spoiled rich preppy boys, greasers and the militant nerd squad (serious) to bullies, cheerleaders and jocks, playing this game for me felt like going back in time and doing some of the things I wanted to do but couldn't. Have to say, boarding school looks more interesting than regular school.Also you can learn various martial arts from a drunken (homeless?) man, which will come in handy later as you fight future "bosses". This game NEEDS a sequel.4.7/5

Posted: August 29, 2014
												I have been playing "bully" since it was can cainm edit (dog eats dog in latin). i have been beating over and over the graphics are a little out of date but its a really fun game. Bully was created By Take-Two and Rockstar Vancouver. You play as a boy named Jimmy Hopkins aged 15 your mum is going on her 55th honeymoon and she leaves you at bullworth academy. If you have played GTA it will feel similar.The gameplay feel much like a GTA game but has diffrent aspects to it. The comedy in this game will never get old. Its genrally a really fun and enjoyable game.final verdict: 10/10

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												The game is pretty funny, I'll give it that. I really liked the rivalry and chemistry between Gary and Jim, though I wish there would be a sequel where Gary returns. The "weapons" are highly creative and enjoyable, and you can even go to classes and pass them after doing various tasks and get good grades. There is a main plotline of course, and "quests" or missions to do in sub-plots while following along the main plot, but like many a high school kid's dream, the end goal is to become the head honcho and live it up with the popularity, as leader of the cliques.Ah, there's also that. Cliques, cliques everywhere! And very cliche too, however being the badass that Jim is, he (you) gets to eventually control all of them and keep them in line. From spoiled rich preppy boys, greasers and the militant nerd squad (serious) to bullies, cheerleaders and jocks, playing this game for me felt like going back in time and doing some of the things I wanted to do but couldn't. Have to say, boarding school looks more interesting than regular school.Also you can learn various martial arts from a drunken (homeless?) man, which will come in handy later as you fight future "bosses". This game NEEDS a sequel.4.7/5

content:
Posted: May 2, 2016
VERY CRASH-FRIENDLY ON WINDOWS 10 8/10 This is a pretty fun game with an interesting story. The game is about Jimmy Hopkins's (a 15 year-old delinquent) year at Bullworth Academy, one of the worst in the country. Jimmy must gain the control of the cliques to become the king of the school, and does so through many ways, though primarily fighting. At the end of each chapter, there is a boss fight with a clique leader. When he defeats the leader, he gains the respect of that clique. Overall the game is very fun and worth a recommend, but it is warned that the game crashes a lot on Windows 10.Pros: Very fun Good story All the characters are unique, with their own fighting styles, appearances, and personalities 6 different cliques Cool weapons Bikes!Cons Very easy The game world is small, even though he transportation is much slower then GTA, the size is not proportional to a GTA game Locked at 30fps (can easily be fixed through here 


How to remove the 30fps framerate cap 
A Guide for Bully: Scholarship Edition
By: MyCocaine

			This guide is written only for the 1.200 patched version of Bully. This is the most up to date version and the one that pretty much everyone on Steam is using. -- By default, Bully's framerate is capped at 30fps.

												Presenting the Seven Wonders of Bullworth City1. The Returning Bike.Whenever you lose it, or maybe when it got stolen, try your garage.2. Free-to-Escape-from Asylum.Record shows an average of 19 fugitives escape each month.3. The All-Energizing Kiss.Despaired from all the bullies, cops, or cars ramming on you? One deep kiss will do the trick.3. The Six Hours of Mystery.No one knows what happens during this blank period. None can, and none will.4. Pirate Invasion."A pirate once invaded the town and beaten." a rumor that is now a local legend.5. Freaks Show.Where a beautiful mermaid and two-in-one girl(s) live in.6. The Endless SummerPerhaps the Melancholy of James Hopkins.7. The Invincible Jimmy.Last but not the least, the king of wonder in Bullworth City.7/10 Recommended for you.

												I loved Bully before it even came out. Very original concept, by a great developer. The result was exacty what I expected. GTA is great, but it's fun to take that whole same mechanic and place it somewhere unusual. There is just so much variety in this game. So much to discover. Such a huge world. It is frustrating that the school schedule doesn't give you enough time to explore sometimes, but I guess that sort of difficulty is what adds another layer of fun.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												This is a great game (or at least was on ps2) but unfortunetly, crashes alot on windows 10. I've completed this game in about a day. I keeped losing progress whenever it crashes. so im gonna  make a list of what not to do to help prevent the game from crashing. do this at your own risk if you choose not to take my advice.1. do not talk to the lunch lady unless youre doing a mission.2. do not try to save a custom outfit.3. dont exit the math class before it ends.4. (spoiler alert) when you fight russell be prepared to do that  fight over and over again. it also lags alot(then again that could just be my computer its self.)5. dont save in the principles office. always save at the boys dorm.6. be careful using the rubberband ball.I reccomend that if you have a ps2, pick up the hard copy of the game. its really cheap. or if you have windows 7, visa, or 8/8.1. it works fine on those. but it still periodiclyall of the things that make my game crash, could be totaly different on your computer. These are just things i have run into.so my final verdict, DO NOT BUY THIS GAME FOR WINDOWS 10 UNLESS YOU LIKE LOSSING PROGRESS AND CONSTANT GAME CRASHES

content:
Posted: November 15, 2016
												I played this on the ps2 when it was first released and the 360 a few years ago now and it is without a doubt my favourite childhood game and I'd recommend it to anyone. However, I've spent the best part of an hour trying to get to the main menu without crashing to no avail, trying all fixes I could find to resolve it; with no luck. I think it's disgusting that this game is still available to be purchased despite the fact that many if not most Windows 10 users can't even play the game.Great game, terrible port...Will be refunding. If you aren't on Windows 10 give it a try to see if you can make progress in the game without crashing, but make sure you only test it for less than an hour and a half to refund if need be. I don't want to completely disparage any Windows 10 users from buying this game but you'll almost definitely be in for a♥♥♥♥♥♥tonne of hassle.

												Open world-action-adventure game. Yeah, you might call it GTA but it is not really. Saint's Row is far more similiar to GTA than this - and that is a good thing. The gameplay is a bit clunky and the graphics look kind of bad (not Sanandreas bad), but they are good enough for everything else it offers. An open world "sandbox" and an awesome story with cutscenes. Definetly get it, at least on sale - but only with a gamepad.

												Fun game. The graphics aren't too good, which is understandable for a game released ages ago, but it's still fun nontheless. I've played this game on the PS2 and that's exactly why I bought this game for the PC, nostalgia. This game is pretty much like GTA, but takes place in a school. You get to beat people up, break into lockers, trespass in some areas and beat more people up. Like GTA, there's always the d-head who catches you if you do these things. Instead of the police, there are school guards (at least what I think they are) they're slow, and you can run away from them, if you got caught by them, you're forced to go to class.9/10. I recommend this game. Go buy it, it's worth it!

content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
Product received for free
												Bully: Scholarship Edition is an awesome game I can say I get nostalgia when I play it.I remember playing Canis Canem Edit (Alternate Title for Bully) on my friend's PS2 and was hooked onto the game.When I saw Scholarship Edition released I was happy as I could play the game again plus with new content like new classes.The story is really interesting and it is very easily to get sidetracked from attending classes as there is quite a bit to do while free roaming around the school campus and nearby town of Bullsworth.The trouble meter is an awesome feature and it shows what rules you are breaking, whether it be truancy, tresspassing or bullying, etc.You can bully others in this game (though that isn't the main focus as it focuses on the other school bullies) but you will be punished for it and will have to face the consequences if caught.Overall great game and sorry for the huge review.I rate Bully an 8/10 due to the fact that because it is an old game it performs poorly on Windows 7 and above with hugh crashes and performance issues on windows 10Don't just assume that because it is a Rockstar Game that it is Grand Theft Auto.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19, 2014
												This is a very good game! My personal favorite game that Rockstar has actually made to be honest.If you love very long single player games, this game is for you. I have been playing this game for 12 hours so far, and have yet to finish it. I am on the 5th (and I believe final) chapter of the game and the quests just keep coming!Bully provides fresh content and it fails to keep you bored. You have tons of quests you can do at any time whether it be taking girls out on dates, egging the boy's dormatory, or keeping your English teacher from being fired by hiding his alchohol stash. On top of that, you can give kids wedgies, shove them into trash cans or lockers, spray paint grafitti all over the place, steal bikes, and so on. There is just so much you can do in this game!Combat is a bit bad in this game though. You might be tasked to protect a nerd from a jock, problem is, you might keep accidentally hitting the nerd because they are in your way or near the jock as you are trying to beat them up and sweep their legs out from under them. And if you are surrounded by enemies, most will just keep tackling you over and over again until you finally just have to bail and run and hope to god you lose them before they take what little health you have left from you. Rockstar defiantly could have made improvements with camera angles and the combat of this game.Overall though, if you like long campaign games and enjoy having so much as your disposal. you should buy Bully. This is a good game and you will not be disappointed!

content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												This game is a classic. One of Rockstar's Finest games. It is essentially a heavily story-driven sandbox game. You're Jimmy Hopkins, a 15 year old ne'er do well who was just dumped at a boarding school by his parents. This school is a living hell. And you thought your high school was bad. Jimmy is a good kid at heart, despite what the title of the game would lead you to believe. It's all a matter of choice. You could either bully kids, or try to help them out. Morality vs. convinience.Expect frequent Catcher in The Rye references, sly sexual humor and typical teenage cursing.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
												I could just go ahead and say "You can give wedgies to little kids and you can grope girls 10/10" like most people do, but this game deserves a lot more than that.This is my favorite game of all times, got it for the ps2 initially and I finished it like 6 times on there. Then I got steam and had to buy it for the pc and I'm so glad I did!It really is a GTA Junior but I like it even more than the original because it's magical! I don't even know how to express myself. The world is so charismatic, the missions are great fun and make sense, the soundtrack is AMAZING and Jimmy is the best sprinter/aimer/sportsman/biker/boxer/student (if you wish to do all the classes), the best main character in general!Story is short but there is much more to it than in that, in fact if you only do the main missions I believe you don't even get 50% completion, so yeah!I recommend this game with all my heart I hope you enjoy it as much as I did. Hell! If you enjoy it a quarter as much as I did you'll still have a blast! :)

												This game is a classic. One of Rockstar's Finest games. It is essentially a heavily story-driven sandbox game. You're Jimmy Hopkins, a 15 year old ne'er do well who was just dumped at a boarding school by his parents. This school is a living hell. And you thought your high school was bad. Jimmy is a good kid at heart, despite what the title of the game would lead you to believe. It's all a matter of choice. You could either bully kids, or try to help them out. Morality vs. convinience.Expect frequent Catcher in The Rye references, sly sexual humor and typical teenage cursing.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												The sun is rising, it's a beautiful day.The alarm clock goes "BEEP BEEP BEEP" and you trampoline yourself into a vertical spine position called standing."My goodness, today is the first day of school" you hastily expel from your innards.That's right Peter, today is the first day of school but not only that my friend. Today is the first day of school at a new school.Your mother and stepfather will soon drop you off with hatred in their hearts at Bullworth Academy.There you will fight your way to the top and have everyone shout your name when you pass them."Bully: Scholarship Edition" they will shout repeatedlyIt will be a wonderful journey and it begins now.Bully: Scholarship Edition or more commonly nicknamed "Jimmy" is the main character of this video game and he's not afraid of showing it right away. The story is about him. The cutscenes star him. This is quite the problem for me because he shaves his head. This is something I do as well, for that reason I have trouble distinguishing fiction from reality and got into trouble with the police. Luckily we live in an age of mystery and magic, you don't need to play as Jimmy anymore. You can use technology called hacking to hack the video game and change the model you play as. I opted first in playing as one the adults as I thought maybe the lady folk around campus would be into more experienced men but no. No model would change the attitude they had against me, this made me sad. Hacking doesn't work on the people in the real world either.Gameplay is "Beat the jocks at dodge ball, play pranks on the preppies, save the nerds, kiss the girl and ultimately navigate the social hierarchy in the worst school around. " and that pretty much catches it all using the umbrella method. Now, I've only played it for 55 minutes but what I experienced during that time was wonderful. I hit people, threw books at people, hit on people, talked to people(thumps up edition), talked to people(thumbsdown edition), bought soda and meeting some kind of creature called a prefect you can easily avoid by just jumping all the time.The gameplay mechanics is what you would expect from a Rockstar PC port, somewhat clunky but generally okay. The game also features all kinds of education based mini games like chemistry, english, math, geography etc. All these subjects and their mechanics are highly representative of the American education system. In conclusion, it’s a beautiful sandbox-style game with beautiful characters and beautiful gameplay.3/10

content:
Posted: October 27, 2015
												Personal Rating: 7/10Ah Bully. This games getting a sequel in 2016 so hopefully people can get hyped for that after they've stopped ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ themselves about Fallout 4. However let's take a look at the first game.Bully is an open world game set in a school. You play as Jimmy Hopkins who is arguabley the biggest♥♥♥♥♥♥on earth at the beginning of the game. Much like Rockstar's other games, you do quests located around the map to advance the story. Very GTA IV like but without any of those silly cars or mass genocides, carried out by helicopters and bowling.Gameplay wise, it's honestly nothing special to be honest. I can't feel connected to Hopkins because he's a♥♥♥♥♥♥ and I can't feel any sympathy for him or any bullies for that matter. I mean, I'm a nerd, in this game you're basically asking me to steal my own lunch money. But the jokes on him, I make my own lunch and bring it with me *pushes glasses up nose*. But nah, it's not fresh. There's nothing convincing me to do any of these actions apart from to advance the story. One new thing they added into this game is classes. No, not Call of Duty classes. As in, actual learning classes like Art, English and Science. You might be thinking "Well what's the point in going to classes? I live the thug life". Well, these classes can eventually give you upgrades and weapons such as stinkbombs, clothing and even a bike (which I never got, apparently my lack of skills in production and art carried over into this game). Each class revolves around a minigame, like in English for example, you have to make as many possible words out of a jumble of letters, or in Art where you have to avoid pencils and stuff to draw a picture? I don't know what they were thinking but it works I suppose.Obviously a big part of the game is combat. But it lacks a certain something. Beat 'em ups and Fighting games have never appealed to me, and Bully is basically a beat 'em up with a couple of minigames slapped on the top, with an unrelatable character and numerous little cracks in this game.However, it's still great. As much as I've complained about this game, it really is a very good game. Graphically wise it might not stand up to today's standards, however they were good for it's time. Some of the characters like the Principal and the Homeless Bloke are well made and I enjoyed the parts of the game they were in. Now obviously I haven't played all of this game, I finished it on my Xbox 360 though so that can sort of give you an idea.The one big problem with the Steam version is that if you try and change the options, such as the size of the screen, the game will crash. Well, it did in my case, so I'm playing the game in a 4:3 window. The game's options are full of bugs that may crash the game, so be careful.

												Bully is a wonderful free-roam, perhaps one of my favourite Rockstar games. The graphics are mediocre by this time, but it's nothing to scoff at either. While the game is buggy and has some issues with AI, it's not usually game-breaking and you'll be too busy beating people up to care.The character depth is great, especially due to the fact that no two characters in Bully are the same, they each have their own personalities and traits, and if you don't think so, just stop to listen to them and maybe you'll see what I mean.The music is suitable and, for the most part, sets the emotion of the scene adequately.Bully is a great game and well worth the price.(P.S. Rockstar, make sequel pls)

content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
NOTICE: Although I am recommending it, I do advise you should try to play one of the Console Versions or at least use a controler for the PC Port.Bully: Scholarship Edition is a lovely game, just ported poorly for PC.I just finished the game, and only experienced 1 crash and 2 FPS drops through all of it. 1 crash was due to using the camera to take pictures of students for the yearbook; Had a FPS drop during the fight under the school and the other in the factory to fight one of the "bosses".I didn't find the controls to be horrendous, they are a bit funny at first, but you'll get use to it after a short time.Story (This subject will lack because the games description will give you a good insight and I don't want to spoil anything) I found the story to be pleasent. It wasn't the best and I found the it to be something like GTA's The Lost and Damned, but not entirely. All in all, I enjoyed it and found it hard at points to stop playing because of it.Gameplay/Controls Gameplay is pretty solid, but using keyboard and mouse can be quite infuriating at at times. Fighting was pain for me at the begining, sometimes I would end up hurting friendly NPC's, because they were in the way of an enemy NPC and using your mouse is how you switch between targets which would cause me to accidently switch to a friendly NPC.Riding your skateboard and bike with WASD can cause you to wreck... quite a bit. It becomes stressful when you are doing a race or an objective that requires you to use your bike.There are 'minigames' so to speak; you can take a side job missions to earn extra cash, go to the carnival, take a trip to a skate park and compete in bike races.Their are collectables such as rubber bands and G&G Cards to snag.I would add tag spots, but they didn't seem perminant but I could be wrong.You also have classes and they are used to give your character upgrades. Example, you complete a Class One Art and you'll get 25% Health Bonus when you kiss a girl. You are not forced to go to class, but the school guards and police officers will chase and attempt to take you to class.Pros:Good StoryLikable CharactersEnjoyable GameplayDifferent From Most Games (That I've played)Cons:Bad PortClucnky ControlsFeels Slightly DatedSummaryI know most people don't recommend it do to it being a bad port, but it is still fully playable.$15 price is not bad at all, I got 20 hours out of it and possibly more if I decide to 100%.I would say, try to get it when there is a Rock Star Publisher Sale going on, then you can probably get it for around $5 - $10.All in all, well rounded game and sadly it doesn't seem to get the recognition that it deserves. One of Rock Stars hidden gems.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
												Bully (aka Canis Canem Edit) is certainly one of those rare gems most people have not heard much of. It seems as if the people of Rockstar had been given complete freedom to include whatever they wanted in this game. The characters are funny, the story is compelling, the mini-games are well implemented and the gameplay is fun. I like how although the map is not huge, you’ll see it change as the seasons change. This expands the possible themes of the game and its pace, and it also gives you a reason to change the protagonist’s clothes to fit the current season and do different things at different events during the game (Christmas, Halloween, Carnival time etc.) There are a ton of Easter eggs and funny scenes within the game if you are willing to find them. I liked every single class (but for English, that cr*p was hard) and the missions were all fun, but somewhat easy. The game is old, and you can tell by its graphics and the overall look, but it is still fun and it'll make you laugh at several points. The worst thing you can say about this game is that it’s not a great pc port. There are weird sounds all around (unless you change some setting in the menu), the FPS are capped at 30 and it’ll take you some time to find out how to skip cutscenes. The camera won’t stay in a fix position as it does in GTA, but there are some things this game does better than its older brother Grand Theft Auto. For instance, you don’t have to start all over again if you fail a mission, and at least people use umbrellas when it’s raining. Oh, and collectables do not float in the air and they are included in the game in such a way in which you don’t really have to look for them if you don’t want to, because you’ll get most as you play the game’s missions. Jimmy is a sort of Holden Caulfield, and that’s great. He may a bit aggressive and not be very smart, but that does not mean he’s malicious either. You really have fun being Jimmy and experiencing once again your time at your high school, even if it was probably not as exciting as in this game. Gary, Pete, all the teachers, the different school gangs, the ost, the minigames, going skateboarding everywhere… they may be all simple things, but they really make this story outstanding and, above everything else, fun.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2015
												I've loved this game ever since it originally came out on PS2. I remember one time I invited a few other people that never played it before to play it and they loved it too! The story is amazing, the graphics are beautiful but not hard on a CPU, and gameplay is, good, I say that because some of the controls are bad and well, sometimes things work in weird ways that seem glitchy compared to certain things in Grand Theft Auto III, which came out a while before this. But either way, here are my ratings for the game:Game itself: 9/10Concept: 10/10 just for originality,Story: 10/10, some offensive stuff but that's one reason it's awesome,Controls (for PC): 4/10, aim mode is Up Arrow and to look around you use the mouse, and to move you use the WASD keys, when do you have time in like a boss battle or something to press Up?Physics (among other things): 5/10, you drop an item, it falls straight down. You jump off something with the Skateboard Bucky gives you early on in the game, you lose a lot of speed and sometimes just comepletely stop. Worst of all when you throw someone onto a street curb in such a way, and this is often, they will have gravity to that spot, meaning, they will be able to stand at a full 45 degree angle and not have to balance or anything.Overall: 8/10, this would have to be my favorite game on PS2 besides Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas and that underrated game called Gun.Thanks for reading this long review!

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Bully is from the creators of the Grand Theft Auto and Red Dead Redemption franchises. This time, instead of a space age, or an urban enviroment, a school. Bully takes place in Bullsworth Acadamy, and is about a young boy, who has been dropped off at this boarding school because of his wreckless behaviour in the past.Along the way you'll meet crazy characters such as a hobo that teaches you kung-fu, nerds, jocks, and of course, the headmaster.It is and open world game, but the world isn't as big as Liberty City, Vice City or San Andreas. However, the world has personality in the character dialouge, and the charm in the enviroments, like graphiti, the carnival and the school corridors. Lessons are fun mini-games, and detentions also have their own mini-games, like lawn mowing or snow shoveling.This game deserves a sequel, and with recent news of Bully getting trademarked, we may have a glimmer of hope for Bully 2.That or it's a moblie port.Rating: 9.5/10

												WARNING: VERY BAD CONTROL SCHEME!  There is partial controller support, meaning it supports controllers but has a lot of problems with them.  Xbox 360 controllers are not plug-and-play, but they work as long as you enable them within the in-game options menu.  The game's default keyboard controls are terrible, and while the game is best played with a controller, it sometimes requires you to use a more accurate aiming tool, like a mouse or tablet, to play the minigames... well, you could probably do the minigames with your joysticks, but it would be unnecessarily difficult.  The minigames are clearly designed for a mouse.That aside, Bully is a nice game for how old it is.  It has decent visuals (nothing special), similar to GTA3 with characters closer to the style of Fable (sort of, see screenshots), and it plays fairly well.  The story has a lot of hilarious moments and some good laughs for people who like absurd phrases.  There are some gross-out moments, as well, so the game may not be for the squeamish.  Immature, snot-nosed brats should love it, though!  ;DThe only gripe I have besides the controls is that the AI is absolutely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.  The characters will just stand around doing the same behavior, even saying the same phrase, non-stop for the entire time you're near them.  I wish the devs would have given NPCs more believable behavior patterns.  That said, if you run through the levels very fast, you will not notice that issue.You can play a bunch of metagames which help progress the story, but there is not much replay value, because the game really isn't that open and offers very few distractions to keep you occupied.  There is very little challenge to the game, but that may be a good thing for some players.Overall, my opinion allows the game a 3/5.  Get it if it's cheap.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												Pros:Another excellent Rockstar sandbox game, worth the price. Give this a go if you like GTA. I also recommend it for those who like GTA games but often find the story missions too difficult. Bully's missions are a lot easier than those found in most GTA games. There's a lot to do outside of the main story too, with countless side-missions, minigames, secrets and unlockables to find. The game's soundtrack is awesome, by the way, composed by Shawn Lee. If you play this game for more than ten minutes the music will have already been stuck in your head.Cons:If you're playing this on Windows 10 you may encounter crashes a fair few times, there are steps that can be taken to minimise the frequency of these crashes. I took these steps but I couldn't eradicate the crashes completely, I may have missed something however. Also, the game is locked at 30 FPS if you're worried about that. It can be brought up to 60 FPS with some tinkering if you like, I didn't mind it all that much. Another issue I had was the audio, outside of cutscenes I thought the characters' voices were too quiet and they were overpowered by the music, even though I had the speech option at max.To sum up, Bully is a unique, funny game with a great story, a fantastic soundtrack, a ton of side missions, a lot of pranks to pull and a lot of characters to interact with. The few technical problems I mentioned are outweighed by this game's qualities.

Posted: December 5, 2011
												Definitely one of Rockstar's more focused efforts in their long line of open games, Bully still succeeds in staying true to the formula with a somewhat, just a bit though, focused narrative and time constraints imposed on the player by the very nature of the game - attending school. Characters and story are memorable and clearly intended as exaggeration of high-school stereotypes, although many come as 1-shots for some reason. One can't help but praise out-of-nowhere dramatic final confrontation which ends up being EXTREMELY satisfying and just, though. Only really negative side I can think of is the fact that this isn't such a great port.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												Bully was a game back in 2006 released for the PS2 that basically offered the gameplay of Grand Theft Auto to minors without penalty.Bully is a game where you play as 15 year old Jimmy Hopkins as he attempts to survive his high school days after his mother and step father drop him off due to their honeymoon. While Jimmy attempts to fit in, he does various jobs for each of the cliques at the School to gain their favour. Whether its getting som D&D pages back for the Nerds, beating up the Jocks for the Preps, or roughing up the Preps for the Greasers, Jimmy does pretty much everything possible to just survive.Gameplay wise, this is a text-book R* sandbox game with its own unique touches. You can go to class where you play mini-games to unlock new abilities, start fights with the various cliques of the school, or just be a delinquent and destroy everything.Bully was one of the most unique R* games in it's gameplay feel. Sure it plays pretty close to the Renderware Grand Theft Auto games (GTA III, Vice City, San Andreas), it has its own unique feel with a pretty interesting plot, some great voice acting, and missions and activities that are fun to play. It's 14.99 and the game is pretty long, so you do get your money's worth.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												Bully on PS2 was one of my favourite games in the Rockstar catalogue back in the day, and so I was excited to get my hands on the Scholarship Edition which promised to bring the world of Bullworth Academy and its surrounding towns into glorious HD life. And whilst textures and draw distance have been improved, B:SE isn't without its issues. The game is noticeably buggy, more so than the original and especially prevalent with the AI behaviour, particularly as you have a whole school's worth of NPCs running about. The new classes/minigames feel tacked on and are of poor quality, with the bonuses you gain in completing them utterly pointless. And call me vain, but I also dislike main character Jimmy Hopkins' new face; I mean, the kid wasn't exactly going to win any male model prizes back in 2006, but his makeover makes it seem like you're now controlling a middle-school aged Wayne Rooney who, in case you don't know, *definitely* isn't a looker. If you need to, give him a quick Google Image Search, and shield your eyes. One of the appeals of the original was saving up enough pocket money to buy new clothing for Jimmy, constantly dressing him up in just enough school uniform mixed with casual items so as to not get busted by prefects for violating the dress code, and so I don't think this demand for superficial consistency is too much of an ask.Despite these complaints, I'd recommend B:SE for any newcomers who never had the chance to play it before. The game is full of charm and accompanied by a brilliant soundtrack, finding a great balance between Rockstar's GTA formula with just enough new ideas to make it seem like a fresh enough experience for both GTA fans as well as those who've begun to grow tired with that series. However if you've already played Bully before, there isn't enough here to live up to the nostalgia, and I'd recommend investing on the PSN version of the original instead. For all its muddy graphics and atrocious framerate, particularly when the outside-school environments open up, the game was perfectly balanced in its original incarnation, without the out of place classes and, certainly, with a much better designed main character.7/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												I come back to this game every year or so just to experience it again. I bought it on PC during the last summer sale because I had finished it so many times on xbox, but I sold both my xbox and games a while ago.I don't think I've ever played a game that stands up so well after nearly a decade since initial release.The story, the characters, the atmosphere, that perfect soundtrack, all are as great as the first time I experienced the game. Although I'm insanely hyped for Red Dead 2, a little part of me was sad that the announcement wasn't a sequel to this game.Bully has pretty simple open world gameplay, but the world that makes me come back everytime. There's a sense of nostalgia that just follows you throughout the game, even if you've never played the game before, the school setting has a really charming old school feeling to it.Can't say enough amazing things about this game. I was thinking about what my favourite game of all time was and I just couldn't pick one, but then I remembered that this game is the only one I still play after finishing it so many times already it doesn't lose any of the magic that made it great.I'm also kind of worried about the sequel to this game, because I don't think a game with atmosphere and characters this perfect can be topped, or even matched. That's how great I think it is.I obviously recommend it. I'll recommend it 50 years from now. It's timeless.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2013
												WARNING: VERY BAD CONTROL SCHEME!  There is partial controller support, meaning it supports controllers but has a lot of problems with them.  Xbox 360 controllers are not plug-and-play, but they work as long as you enable them within the in-game options menu.  The game's default keyboard controls are terrible, and while the game is best played with a controller, it sometimes requires you to use a more accurate aiming tool, like a mouse or tablet, to play the minigames... well, you could probably do the minigames with your joysticks, but it would be unnecessarily difficult.  The minigames are clearly designed for a mouse.That aside, Bully is a nice game for how old it is.  It has decent visuals (nothing special), similar to GTA3 with characters closer to the style of Fable (sort of, see screenshots), and it plays fairly well.  The story has a lot of hilarious moments and some good laughs for people who like absurd phrases.  There are some gross-out moments, as well, so the game may not be for the squeamish.  Immature, snot-nosed brats should love it, though!  ;DThe only gripe I have besides the controls is that the AI is absolutely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.  The characters will just stand around doing the same behavior, even saying the same phrase, non-stop for the entire time you're near them.  I wish the devs would have given NPCs more believable behavior patterns.  That said, if you run through the levels very fast, you will not notice that issue.You can play a bunch of metagames which help progress the story, but there is not much replay value, because the game really isn't that open and offers very few distractions to keep you occupied.  There is very little challenge to the game, but that may be a good thing for some players.Overall, my opinion allows the game a 3/5.  Get it if it's cheap.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2015
												I've loved this game ever since it originally came out on PS2. I remember one time I invited a few other people that never played it before to play it and they loved it too! The story is amazing, the graphics are beautiful but not hard on a CPU, and gameplay is, good, I say that because some of the controls are bad and well, sometimes things work in weird ways that seem glitchy compared to certain things in Grand Theft Auto III, which came out a while before this. But either way, here are my ratings for the game:Game itself: 9/10Concept: 10/10 just for originality,Story: 10/10, some offensive stuff but that's one reason it's awesome,Controls (for PC): 4/10, aim mode is Up Arrow and to look around you use the mouse, and to move you use the WASD keys, when do you have time in like a boss battle or something to press Up?Physics (among other things): 5/10, you drop an item, it falls straight down. You jump off something with the Skateboard Bucky gives you early on in the game, you lose a lot of speed and sometimes just comepletely stop. Worst of all when you throw someone onto a street curb in such a way, and this is often, they will have gravity to that spot, meaning, they will be able to stand at a full 45 degree angle and not have to balance or anything.Overall: 8/10, this would have to be my favorite game on PS2 besides Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas and that underrated game called Gun.Thanks for reading this long review!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2014
												Bully. It's GTA, but without blood and deadly weapons, and instead of playing as an adult man, you play as Jimmy Hopkins. A 15 year old kid who's aggressive and a fighter, but not truly malicious. He only gives people what they have coming to them.Bully takes place in Bullworth, a town in New England. Your mom, well, Jimmy's mom, drops you off at Bullworth Academy. A boarding school. The school is full of bullies and corrupt teachers and it's up to you to put a stop to it.The game's storyline will guide you through six chapters (There are 65 missions, the sixth chapter is an endless free-roam chapter, giving you the chance to complete non-storyline missions and to collect collectables.) Each of them takes place in a different weather season. The missions vary, it's never the same. One time you're cleaning a rat infested library and the next time you're helping a teacher escape from a psychiatric hospital. As Jimmy, your main goal is to bring peace to the school by helping and befriending the five school cliques: The Nerds, the Jocks, the Bullies and the Preppies.Of course you'll have to go to class. These classes are: English, gym, geography, math (ew), music, shop, art, photography and biology. They are simple mini-games which become noticeably harder every time you attend them and make progress. You'll also have to deal with a time schedule. You can skip class, but you won't get any rewards if you do so and prefects will catch you if they see you outside of class. Jimmy, your character, is highly customizable. You can buy clothes, change your hairstyle and more. You can even buy a bike, a go-kart or a scooter if you saved up enough cash. Money can be earned by either taking a paper route, doing missions for townies or students or by completing storyline missions. You've got weapons. No, they are not guns and no you can't kill people. There's a super slingshot, you can use firecrackers, stink bombs, eggs, a bag of marbles, a bottle rocket launcher and so much more. You can also pick up one of the many objects around you (umbrella's, vases, bottles) and use them as a weapon.Interacting with your fellow students is fun too. You can talk to them, give them presents, put them in trash bins, punch them in the face (aka bully them) and even kiss them. (This only applies to several girls and yes, you can kiss some guys too if you're into that.)The game has a very impressive map size. You can explore the entire school, the school grounds, the town, a fully functional theme park, an industrial park and a few more awesome places. There are many collectables scattered around the map too.Bully may be pretty good, but it's not perfect. The graphics are rather outdated, the sound isn't that amazing and you will have to deal with odd controls and some bugs. But don't worry! It doesn't kill the fun. Bully is an amazing game and there's much to do. And for only $14.99 - £9.99 - €9.99, it's certainly worth it. Go buy it! I recommend you it!

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												Absolutely fantastic game. 2nd favorite Rockstar game, only behind Red Dead. (BTW, LORD GABEN BETTER PUT IT ON STEAM.) Bully revolves around the daily academy life of Jimmy Hopkins, a fifteen year old troublemaker and an all-around badass.The game is really cool because it's open world on the campus of Bullworth Academy. Now, this can be great for the 2 kinds of game players that exist. The ones that actually play a storyline and are afraid to be a♥♥♥♥♥♥in a videogame (Me), or someone who doesn't give a damn and just screws around hitting girls and giving prefects the wedgie of their life (Also Me).Pros:+Humor. LOTS of humor+Likeable Hero+Classroom Aspect+Voice acting (GOLD)+Not restricted to just the campus+Nonrepetetive storyline+Intresting story about betrayal and, well, BULLIES!+Antagonist is a♥♥♥♥♥♥ (I like that)+YOU choose the way you play. Lover or Hater kind of thing+Unlockables+Character Customization+Interesting soundtrack+Fun Gameplay+Easy Achievements, sorta, on console+A Pretty lengthy storyline+Crime and punishment system is realistic-ish and is reasonable+Lenient Prefect escape systemCons:-Vague respect system-Graphics are a little painful to look at, but for it's time it's alright-Controls are something special-No AchievementsThe game is very good, and I give it an 89/100. This is also the first game I got all achievements on (LONG weekend).An underrated game that you should buy.Have fun hiding in trashcans, shoving Algie into a locker, beating up Tad, and making out with Mandy (or Eunice... if you're into that).

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												What you need to know about Bully: Scholarship Edition+ 15 years-old version of GTA+ A lot of mini-games and sidequests+ Creative weaponries, vehicles, and upgrades attainable through side missions+ A fine thin-line between sheer innocence of a young boy and savage sarcasm judging irresponsible adults doing/telling youths to do irresponsible down to illegal errands+ On its core, an excellent game with interesting concept well executedHowever I can't fully recommend due to tons of compatibility issues due to bad port (especially on newer system)- Game is capped at 30 FPS (there is an exe. "patch" for 60 fps out there in the internet, but it leads to more bugs)- Bad engine that can't handle dated graphic. Can't even set shadow on without having the game unplayable- Crashing when tweaking with graphics options (and resolved without doing anything)- Choppy mouse and camera control (badly affects aiming in first-person and bike control)- Relatively short main campaign story+/- As you play as 15 years old, your world is limited as a 15 years old+/- Perhaps is better played with controller rather than Kb&MDespite all the cons, the game is still a great nostalgia trip if happened to play the PS2 version. The Scholarship Edition added a few extra side-missions and classes, which could be good or bad depending on your tastes (I just find them annoying, but meh)

content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
												In Bully you play as Jimmy Hopkins, 15 year old problem teen who right at the begginning of the game is being left at Bullworth Academy boarding school by his mother and new step father who are about to leave for their honeymoon.When Jimmy first arrives at Bullworth he quickly learns he's at the bottom of the foodchain in the school and sets out to literally beat up each Cliques leaders to earn their respect.The game controls and plays very similarly to GTA with some differences.Jimmy is expected by teachers and prefects which act as the "police" within the school  grounds to attend classes on weekdays and go to bed on curfew.Nothing stops you from skipping class or staying up late, but if you get caught it can mean detention.Each class has its own minigame which gets harder each time you pass, and in the post-game you unlock some new classes you couldn't do at the start of the year.Combat is very similar to that of GTAIV, but heavily improved upon. There are many moves and techniques Jimmy can learn such as sweeping under someones legs to knock them over or uppercuts.When using a grapple on another student Jimmy is able to "bully" them in various ways.Overall I'd say this is one of Rockstars best releases to date, and one of the few games released by them that I still fully enjoy.If you enjoy GTA you're pretty much guaranteed to enjoy this.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												was running from a prefect and he got stuck in a wall420/360 would get stuck againEDIT: Holy nutballs I based a review off a rare glitch? Damn must have I been high, erm.Bully:Scholarship Edition is a third person game that takes place in a VERY stereotypical american high-school, if you're looking to do a Columbine this isn't for you unless you want to substitute with a slingshot or spud gun.In one mission you break into the girls dorm and steal panties.The game is full of fun minigames, hell some of the classes are minigames in themselves. (I don't count Maths and English as minigames, ok.)You can basically do whatever you want in a school-themed game and not have any real life consequences, go ahead and shoot that fat nerd with the spud gun.You've got the Nerds, the Preppies, the Greasers and i'm pretty sure everyone would know there would be Jocks in this kind of game, each with their own theme whenever you're fighting someone a part of their faction, speaking of themes, when you get the game you get the soundtrack too for free, some of the soundtrack (like the theme that plays when a prefect chases you down) sounds like 80s cop music and it's just so memorable it's no surprise that it may get stuck in your head quickly.Let's just get to the most fun parts, you can beat people up of course, you could throw itching powder at people and watch them thoughtlessly scratch themselves, you can throw stinkbombs and firecrackers, shoot a slingshot, bottle rocket launcher (kinda like fireworks), and spud gun, make out with several different girls (Or guys, don't talk about that seriously.).The game offers at least 15 hours of gameplay unless you just speedrun it and have no fun at all outside of the main storyline.Conclusion: 8.5/10, I absolutely wish for a sequel, and a sequel with many more hours of gameplay, Happy nerd hunting, gamers!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
												In Bully you play as Jimmy Hopkins, 15 year old problem teen who right at the begginning of the game is being left at Bullworth Academy boarding school by his mother and new step father who are about to leave for their honeymoon.When Jimmy first arrives at Bullworth he quickly learns he's at the bottom of the foodchain in the school and sets out to literally beat up each Cliques leaders to earn their respect.The game controls and plays very similarly to GTA with some differences.Jimmy is expected by teachers and prefects which act as the "police" within the school  grounds to attend classes on weekdays and go to bed on curfew.Nothing stops you from skipping class or staying up late, but if you get caught it can mean detention.Each class has its own minigame which gets harder each time you pass, and in the post-game you unlock some new classes you couldn't do at the start of the year.Combat is very similar to that of GTAIV, but heavily improved upon. There are many moves and techniques Jimmy can learn such as sweeping under someones legs to knock them over or uppercuts.When using a grapple on another student Jimmy is able to "bully" them in various ways.Overall I'd say this is one of Rockstars best releases to date, and one of the few games released by them that I still fully enjoy.If you enjoy GTA you're pretty much guaranteed to enjoy this.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												Absolutely fantastic game. 2nd favorite Rockstar game, only behind Red Dead. (BTW, LORD GABEN BETTER PUT IT ON STEAM.) Bully revolves around the daily academy life of Jimmy Hopkins, a fifteen year old troublemaker and an all-around badass.The game is really cool because it's open world on the campus of Bullworth Academy. Now, this can be great for the 2 kinds of game players that exist. The ones that actually play a storyline and are afraid to be a♥♥♥♥♥♥in a videogame (Me), or someone who doesn't give a damn and just screws around hitting girls and giving prefects the wedgie of their life (Also Me).Pros:+Humor. LOTS of humor+Likeable Hero+Classroom Aspect+Voice acting (GOLD)+Not restricted to just the campus+Nonrepetetive storyline+Intresting story about betrayal and, well, BULLIES!+Antagonist is a♥♥♥♥♥♥ (I like that)+YOU choose the way you play. Lover or Hater kind of thing+Unlockables+Character Customization+Interesting soundtrack+Fun Gameplay+Easy Achievements, sorta, on console+A Pretty lengthy storyline+Crime and punishment system is realistic-ish and is reasonable+Lenient Prefect escape systemCons:-Vague respect system-Graphics are a little painful to look at, but for it's time it's alright-Controls are something special-No AchievementsThe game is very good, and I give it an 89/100. This is also the first game I got all achievements on (LONG weekend).An underrated game that you should buy.Have fun hiding in trashcans, shoving Algie into a locker, beating up Tad, and making out with Mandy (or Eunice... if you're into that).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15, 2014
												9/10Another great game by Rockstar!Short summary: A child/ younger persons GTA. No explicit language only minor ( B word for female dog is the strongest language used). Guns are replaced with school like weapons (eg Slingshot). Bikes and skateboards instead of cars.Has a good story and enjoyable gameplay. I quite like the idea that you are a bully to bullies rather than just a bully at a school. I thought the characters were rich with interesting personalites. The gameplay is very fun and even the school subject quests are entertaining (except for english, I found that one a bit boring). The side quests for NPCs are great fun, though there were times when I really wanted to punch the quest giver (which I eventually did). Even at a school there is a wide range of fun weapons to play with and a reasonable sized open world to explore.Overall I found this game throughrally enjoyable. I loved the story and I thought that the gameplay was excellent. I would reccommend that Rockstar fans should definatly buy it. If you have never played one of their games (GTA series, Red Dead Redemption etc.) I reccommend giving this game a go.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												Bully is a pretty cool game, it is reminiscent to GTA in that you can free roam and openly accept missions from random people, as well as complete the main missions. You play as Jimmy who has been expelled from another school and has arrived at Bullworth Academy, and the principal is determined to change his ways. The game is full of fun, hilarity and mayhem. You help Jimmy make his way through the year of Bullworth by helping the bullies, teaming up with the nerds, kissing some girls and even asssiting some of the teachers, there are a few missions which I found annoying but overall the missions are quite well spread and well thought out, the story is cool, there are seasonal changes around the school like Christmas time (my favourite was Halloween, you'll see why). It's a really cool game and worth the money you end up spending.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												Bought this game more for nostalgia than anything else due to having the same game under a different name of 'Canis Canem Edit' for the PS2 but it had a horrible glitch nearing the end so i could never actually complete the storyl ine as it always crashed at the same point.The game itself is fun, imagine GTA but as a kid....in a school....with a slingshot and other amusing weapons xD Make your way through the game and choose your alliances well, wanna be friendly with the jocks? go for it,bully everyone and chuck them in a bin! Nerds are for you? go for it, protect them from....being chucked in a bin. Build teen romances and go on a date to the carnival, why not?There's also the fun addition of the classes where you have to do mini games/solve puzzles in order to pass but if that type of gaming isnt for you then just skip class! But beware of those pain in the butt prefects! Oh and the coppers if you go off school grounds!

Posted: December 30, 2013
												In this game you play as 15 year old Delinquent Jimmy Hopkins as he goes through life in his new boarding school, bullworth. Bullworth has 4 types of students. The Greasers, leather jacket wearing punks who try to act tough, The Nerds, weak mischievous fools who usually use stink bombs on bullies, The Preps, High life living chaps who only associate with other wealthy students and they also love the sport of boxing, and finally the Jocks, they rule the school and everyone knows it. In this game you can beat up practically anything from guys to girls to rats. You can go into town and visit different shops like the barber shop. You can go on panty raids. You can vandalize walls. You can prank people. You can do every bad thing you could have done in school.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2014
												This is certainly one of the best games Rockstar has ever made. Why? Because it's incredibly unique. You play Jimmy, a (possibly 90's?) schoolkid which was sent to Bullworth, at which he spends most of his time. He's a Bully, but a good guy at heart.The game continuesly opens up and gives you more and more tools to play around with, while the Story is pretty appealing since there's a bunch of change and you won't often see the same mission twice.Though, there is one negative point: The PC Port and KB/M controls are absolutely terrible. If you're going to buy this, make sure you have a controller, otherwise it's not bearable. Don't worry about not being able to aim properly, since you won't shoot too often either way, and when you have to, it isn't hard.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												While this PC port comes with awful controls, you can customize them, or do what I do and use a 360 controller.I'll start this review by saying Bully is one of my favorite games of all time, I had it on the Playstation 2, and I kept my PS2 for 2 years until I discovered this was on steam, where I bought this and donated my PS2. Bully has what I consider a great storyline, plenty of weapons and perks, great AI, good replayablility (I've beaten the story, so I loaded a save file and have just been free roaming this whole time. You can unlock a moped, and eventually a go-kart along with a bunch of different weapons from bags of marbles to potato guns. When you first arrive at the school, you are hated for being the dumb new kid. As the game goes on, you gain respect for doing multiple missions, which is how you are treated. I'd say this game is worth $15 but during sales its gone down to $3 or $7. This is a must have in my opinion, after you complete the first chapter you get to go into the local town and cause mayhem, and with a developer such as rockstar you really can't go wrong.The modding community is not what is could(should) be, I was able to download a mod to put the super spudgun into the game but I've only found a few others (One that added cars, different outfits, etc) OverallI'd give this a 10/10.

												Bully: Scholarship Edition is an excellent school-based RPG-like game. You first start off in a school, unable to get out of it in the first chapter. But in the second you are able to roam freely in most of the world. The quests/missions are fun to do and staying out of school can be tricky sometimes. Classes in school give you things such as more accuracy for your slingshot, kissing girls can give you more health and some lessons unlock you new clothing. Overall I'd rate this game as 8.5/10You should try it out.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												Jimmy Hopkins, a young delinquent teen, gets sent to the notoriously bigoted Bullworth Academy by his mother, who's caught up in another fling with an older man. He learns his way around the school and makes friends and enemies (well, pretty much just enemies). Taking down clique after clique, he clashes with Gary, a teenage sociopath, for the title of the ruler of the school.I liked this game! The story was amusing and there were several interesting characters. However, the voice acting was painful and the graphics weren't the best Rockstar could have done. The music was GREAT and there was an intricate web of characters and quests to mess around with if the main story got a bit boring. The fighting was a bit strange at first, with unnatural keyboard positions forcing me to twist my hands around each other, but you get used to it, and by the end of the game you're a champ.Basically GTA for teenagers.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
												Great game. If you are using an Windows 10, according to others you MAY experience frequent crashes. I've played this on Windows 7 and 8, and I was actually able to complete the full story without any crashes. It's a heavy game however. If you want max settings PLUS a solid framerate, you're definitely going to need pretty high specs. I'm using GTX 960 and I'm getting 60 FPS on max settings. Mind you there is a released executable which replaces the original one, removing the 30 FPS limit. I'd only recommend getting that if you have 8 or more GB of ram. Other than that, it's a really juicy story, lots of fun, and can easily be modded. 10/10.

Posted: November 25, 2016
												One of rockstars best and sort of a hidden gem. It's open world but it has the qualities of a small map design with a nice flow and realism. Game mechanics are actually fairly challenging yet simple in concept. Wish it was more fleshed out storywise near the end but really I just didn't want the game to stop it's very endearing. Graphics are nothing to write home about but they don't seem dated and fit the theme well. Sound and music is great if a little repetitve with some tracks.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16
												OK, so here's my take on the crashing thing:THIS GAME CRASHES. A LOT. It crashes roughly on-par with any Bethesda game with mods or memory issues, which is maybe twice every couple of hours. I played a full hour before I even found my first crash.I've seen A LOT of people giving a variety of stories on their own experiences with the crashes. Some saying extreme things, like the game doesn't even run in the first place, or that they can place only about 10 minutes before it crashes. I haven't experienced this.My first experience with the crash was by the mission "Save Algie", which is maybe the 4th or 5th mission in the game. I figured, "Oh, there it is-- the mythical crashes!" No problem, I thought, I'll just load a save..Oh..Oh... I forgot to save since the beginning of the game.SO BUY AT YOUR OWN RISK-- Be aware that Steam will refund the game if you decide you don't want it within 2 hours of gameplay; I would DEFINITELY recommend this game, crashes and all, if it were less than 10$, so definitely get it if it's on saleThe game itself is amazing; I've played it on every console I've ever owned, I've played it since I was a small child, I can even associate many of the events of my early life to playing the game. I even went back on the day I graduated high school to play the game with my friends. It's an instant classic and is tons of good fun, so this game would be golden if not for it's technical issues.All of this said, I *can* recommend the game with a bit of an asterisk next to it: SAVE OFTEN. Do a mission, and return to the dorms to save. I, myself, can have plenty of fun with this game so long as I remember to save after every event, which is not too hard as there's various places to save in the game. That said, if you do buy the game and find you crash too frequently to return and save your game, then feel free to refund it.TO SUMMARIZE: The game *does* crash, but I think it's a managable issue that makes this game worth it depending on your definition of "worth it"-- i recommend potential buyers buy the game, see what severity they have of the issues, and decide for themselves if they want a refund.Oh, and of course, this isn't to say that Rockstar or /anyone/ shouldn't patch the game-- Come on. If Steam is gonna pull 15$ in on this game, then they need to make sure it isn't working worse than their FREE games. It's not that dated-- I can play Wolfenstein 3D with minimal issues on Steam but can't make a PS2-era game work. Bull.

												Great game. If you are using an Windows 10, according to others you MAY experience frequent crashes. I've played this on Windows 7 and 8, and I was actually able to complete the full story without any crashes. It's a heavy game however. If you want max settings PLUS a solid framerate, you're definitely going to need pretty high specs. I'm using GTX 960 and I'm getting 60 FPS on max settings. Mind you there is a released executable which replaces the original one, removing the 30 FPS limit. I'd only recommend getting that if you have 8 or more GB of ram. Other than that, it's a really juicy story, lots of fun, and can easily be modded. 10/10.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												One of rockstars best and sort of a hidden gem. It's open world but it has the qualities of a small map design with a nice flow and realism. Game mechanics are actually fairly challenging yet simple in concept. Wish it was more fleshed out storywise near the end but really I just didn't want the game to stop it's very endearing. Graphics are nothing to write home about but they don't seem dated and fit the theme well. Sound and music is great if a little repetitve with some tracks.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16
												OK, so here's my take on the crashing thing:THIS GAME CRASHES. A LOT. It crashes roughly on-par with any Bethesda game with mods or memory issues, which is maybe twice every couple of hours. I played a full hour before I even found my first crash.I've seen A LOT of people giving a variety of stories on their own experiences with the crashes. Some saying extreme things, like the game doesn't even run in the first place, or that they can place only about 10 minutes before it crashes. I haven't experienced this.My first experience with the crash was by the mission "Save Algie", which is maybe the 4th or 5th mission in the game. I figured, "Oh, there it is-- the mythical crashes!" No problem, I thought, I'll just load a save..Oh..Oh... I forgot to save since the beginning of the game.SO BUY AT YOUR OWN RISK-- Be aware that Steam will refund the game if you decide you don't want it within 2 hours of gameplay; I would DEFINITELY recommend this game, crashes and all, if it were less than 10$, so definitely get it if it's on saleThe game itself is amazing; I've played it on every console I've ever owned, I've played it since I was a small child, I can even associate many of the events of my early life to playing the game. I even went back on the day I graduated high school to play the game with my friends. It's an instant classic and is tons of good fun, so this game would be golden if not for it's technical issues.All of this said, I *can* recommend the game with a bit of an asterisk next to it: SAVE OFTEN. Do a mission, and return to the dorms to save. I, myself, can have plenty of fun with this game so long as I remember to save after every event, which is not too hard as there's various places to save in the game. That said, if you do buy the game and find you crash too frequently to return and save your game, then feel free to refund it.TO SUMMARIZE: The game *does* crash, but I think it's a managable issue that makes this game worth it depending on your definition of "worth it"-- i recommend potential buyers buy the game, see what severity they have of the issues, and decide for themselves if they want a refund.Oh, and of course, this isn't to say that Rockstar or /anyone/ shouldn't patch the game-- Come on. If Steam is gonna pull 15$ in on this game, then they need to make sure it isn't working worse than their FREE games. It's not that dated-- I can play Wolfenstein 3D with minimal issues on Steam but can't make a PS2-era game work. Bull.

Posted: July 9, 2016
												I've had tremendous difficulies trying to get this game to run properly. As things currently stand, there really is no option that would yield in excess of 45minutes of gameplay on Win10.  No matter what you do with the compatibility settings, no matter what you do wih CPU core affinity setting - nothing manages to mend the utter mess that this game is on a Win10 platform. I've tried two different hardware configs, quad core i5 with a discrete AMD GPU and a dual core i3 with Intel HD5500 graphics chip. Both suffer from the same kind of crashes occuring in seemingly reliable intervals.My advice would be to definitely wait for a sale ( I bought it for measly $3 ) and also to not be afraid of relying on Steam's refund policy in case you find out that the game runs poorly on your system as well.

Posted: November 4, 2014
												Bully: Scholarship Edition is a fun free roam type game. You're a 16? year old schoolboy who is sent to a boarding school called "Bullworth Academy" by you're parents.The game is fun but the framereate is capped at 30. While playing you can be a bully if you really want to, but you can also be nice to the nerds.Pros:- Free roam- Fun missions- Almost everythingCons:- Combat gets old after a while- 30FPS capGet this game if you can afford it, you will not be sorry.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
												It's rare that a developer goes from make a adult game about crime with very adult themes. To making a game about a high school kid who moves to a school for child delinquents and socially challenged kids, but in a lot of ways Bully is like a GTA. For example Bully is a giant open world with stuff to collect, bike races to do, arcade games to play, and much more to just kind of find.The mission structure is very similar to GTA, you do a bunch of work for one of the factions;like the jocks or the nerds, and the more the more you do work for one faction it can effect your standing with others. Which in turn can effect the way some of the people treat you at school. The combat is very similar but instead of machine guns and rocket launches. Your playing with slingshots and stink bombs. There are also a lot of things that are different about Bully that really makes it feel like your in high school it feel very structured, but that's not a bad thing at all. Like you have classes two times a day everyday until you pass the highest level of that class, and of you don't go the prefects or any adult of authority. All the classes have there own perks like one of the classes shows you where all the collectibles, and unlike the protagonists in GTA jimmy is 15 and needs his sleep so if your out past 2 you just pass out on the spot which can make some night missions feel a little too time restrictive.The story starts you out in a car ride with you and your mom and what seems to be your new stepdad. They then drop you off in the front of Bullyworth academy where you meet the principle and some of the teacher, but the fun starts to come in when you go to your dorm room and meet your new friend Gary, who is a sociopath, i don't know how else to put it.You soon start to become manipulated by him, and you two soon go your separate ways and you start to see less and less of him. You then start to do work for the other factions of the school. Playing Bully it kind of puts you back and makes you think about your time in high school, I know the archetypes aren't as plain and simple as they are in Bully but it does a great job of boiling a lot of the high school experience down to a 20 hour game.Then there are a few technical issues with bully I didn't really have too many other then the game crash on me a couple of times, and that just sucks after that happened for the first time a started saving much more frequently. I can't really say definitely how the game will turn out for you, but it didn't seem to bad. From my experience with it. Over all the game is well made but parts of it just seem kind of repetitive and broken;overall though I think it's a great game.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												Old, cheap and yet an extremely entertaining game! I wasn't expecting much from it, but the game itself is very intriguing and exciting, indeed. Voice acting is exruciating, in the sense that the audio files themselves are low quality, and this shifts during the game - from good to bad, vice versa. ! BEWARE ! It ships with a .exe that is made to glorify the poor hardware of the Microsoft Xbox 360, alas they've limited the framerates to 30FPS. It is completely unplayable as the mouse-delay is unbearable. So pick up the free .exe made from a user on the Internet that enables x>30 FPS - make a copy of the original .exe as some missions WILL be glitched.Other than that, the story is really fun, voice acting is pretty natural and the overall world is very attractive, esp. during winter. It's a little small and there is a great lack of side mission, in my opinion. The game compensates that lack of side missions with stellar story missions! This game is *fully* worth your money, and so will a sequel be.. I hope. ;)8,2/10

Posted: May 5, 2014
												The story itself is entertaining and the humour in this game is top notch, as you'd expect from Rockstar. The soundtrack to this game is, in my opinion, fantastic and adds to the experience. However, this game would have a significantly higher rating if it wasn't for the quality of the port. The sound quality is not the highest and I found the control scheme, which was designed for a controller, awkward on a keyboard and a mouse. Before you buy this game you should take into account that some people who have bought this game have had problems, which I lucky didn't have. To summarise, the story and the premise of the game is good however the quality of the port is not the best. Despite its flaws I would recommend it.

content:
Posted: April 23, 2015
												Definitely one of my favorite games of all time, I played so many weeks worth of hours on the ps2, doing all the quests, getting all the content, romancing students, and decided to buy it on pc since it's now my main source for games...the sheer amount of things you can do in this game--the storyline and its quests are amazing by itself but in addition there are dozens of side quests to complete and items to acquire. Jimmy's room becomes sort of a trophy case for all your achievements in game and it's rewarding to try to get everything you can. As well as that, exploring the world is very fun and rewarding, especially given that you have limitations such as a curfew, so biking around the city at night leads to cops chasing you for ages.Amazing game, I would not hesitate to recommend it to anyone.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												I remember putting this game into my PS2 way back when thinking it would just be Grand Theft Auto in a school. But boy was I happy that I was wrong. Everything about Bully, whether it be its characters, atmosphere, or even its soundtrack, just gives it way more personality than some Grand Theft Autos. It never feels like a chore to play, with more varied missions that keep it interesting long after you'd usually get bored with a GTA campaign. When I saw it on the Summer Sale, I got without hesitation and started my journey through Bullworth Academy for my 4th time. The only complaint I have with the game is that the towns outside of the school never feel as fleshed out or interesting. But that and minor glitches aside, Bully is a fenominal game. And if you have a controller nearby to use, Bully: Scholarship Edition is a fenominal port.
