												Bully is essentially GTA in a school setting. Great story and pacing, the action is solid too with "creative" weapons like fire crackers and other projectiles from chemistry class and the guns from the nerds. I like the fact that you would "want" to attend class in order to improve your fighting skills (gym) and weapons (chemistry) and social skills (bonus from kissing girls - art class).Finished the game with 60% completion and still lots to do. Must buy for fans of the GTA series. Auto-buy if on sale (like I did last summer sale)

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												     Probably Rockstar's best game. There isn't anything that really needs to be said about this game other than that it's just game, no stupid tutorials, no unnecessary features, it is just done well with just the right amount of stuff. Not only that, it follows a really unique gameplay style (more kid friendly than their edgy Manhunt too) which is pretty fun to play, a nice story that actually shows how bad bullying is and shows Jimmy being rewarded for being a "good" character, and a great port to the PC. This doesn't really need to be mentioned, but there isn't any problem with controls, or any bugs, or any problems at all, it does every really well and it feels really nice on PC. If you need me to describe what makes this game so good I will easily describe what makes this game so good (since there is a lot).This game's story is just great. There is so much to it and it is so great. It's all about characterization, but still manages to focus on gameplay and problems in the game world. Each chapter shows you gaining the respect of each clique, while showing you not only what their stereotypical clique is, but what each character there is like, which can be pretty funny, or if not, interesting to listen to. I don't think there is any part where I was really bored, which is great. There are also side missions which typically are teachers asking you to do things for them, and are actually somewhat linear themselves. These missions really give you an idea of what the people are like in this game in the background, and gives you a whole world to immerse yourself in. It really does well with the immersion, especially with just how humorous the world is (it's showing that the whole world is almost literally out to get him, and that not only are the teachers idiots, drunks, or evil, but the kids are essentially stereotypes who aren't interesting, but interesting at the same time, something you have to love about this game). Overall, it's really a great experience that you'd have to see for yourself on why it's so great.The gameplay style is pretty interesting too since you play as a 15 year old in a really bad school and neighborhood. There isn't any killing or weapons, and because of that, it focuses more on melee combat and combos, and special stuff like eggs and stink bombs. Other than the combat, there are still stores and an open world like GTA, just a lot smaller, so you focus more on using the map to your advantage and experiencing the importance of each area. Also, there are fun minigames like the Challenges for save points and the Carnival, which both reward you with cool stuff. If nothing else, it's a pretty worthwhile experience just because it's something new, but it's a lot more than that.Overall, this game is a lot of fun and definitely worth paying even full price for. You'll definitely get your money out of this and more. I really can't describe anything more than that so for the best idea of what this game is about you'll have to play it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												A small town GTA-like game about an increadibly aggressive but at the same time noble boy at the Bullworth Academy. It surely is not a perfect game, but still worth playing in my oppinion, because of its unique scenario and storyline. If you want to try it, pick it up at a sale, it is often available at very low prices.Overall the story was nice, very unrealistic at times, but still nice. It features some very odd humor and a highly stereotypical view at US school environments. The mission design seemed to me to be a lot easier on the player than the GTA 3 and IV series of games (which were frustratingly hard and unforgiving at times). I think of this as a mostly positive thing, but some missions like most of the races just felt a bit too easy. The game has five story chapters including a lot of separate missions and additionally has a bunch of minigames called classes which can be accessed at specific day times or are forced upon you if the school agents catch you while classes are running. Most of these classes were quite OK and revolve around pressing the right buttons when signalled or dragging icons to marked places. One of the classes on the other hand was so hard that I skipped it all along after three retries.The game was first released in 2006 and was ported to PC in 2008, a few months before GTA IV was released. The graphics level more resembles GTA San Andreas than GTA IV and looks quite ugly by 2013 standards. There are also quite a lot of rendering and texture glitches and a 30 frames per second limit in the PC version. The latter can be solved by a modified executable file (check the Steam guides) which works mostly fine but breaks one mission. Even if the PC port was overly hungry for resources (I do not know, but most Rockstar ports are) this didn't affect me much anymore because the game ran very smooth on the highest settings on hardware from 2013.I cannot state much about the keyboard/mouse control scheme, which other commentators stated to be horrific (which would resemble the situation of the GTA 3 and IV series ports) because I played the game with an Xbox 360 wireless controller through the PC adapter. Played with the controller the game's handling didn't feel so bad, but could have been done a bit better at times. The combat, even though there were quite a lot of moves to be acquired throughout the game, most of the times felt quite annoying. The vehicle mechanics like skateboard, bikes and go-carts didn't feel bad at all.

Posted: April 23, 2015
												Definitely one of my favorite games of all time, I played so many weeks worth of hours on the ps2, doing all the quests, getting all the content, romancing students, and decided to buy it on pc since it's now my main source for games...the sheer amount of things you can do in this game--the storyline and its quests are amazing by itself but in addition there are dozens of side quests to complete and items to acquire. Jimmy's room becomes sort of a trophy case for all your achievements in game and it's rewarding to try to get everything you can. As well as that, exploring the world is very fun and rewarding, especially given that you have limitations such as a curfew, so biking around the city at night leads to cops chasing you for ages.Amazing game, I would not hesitate to recommend it to anyone.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												I remember putting this game into my PS2 way back when thinking it would just be Grand Theft Auto in a school. But boy was I happy that I was wrong. Everything about Bully, whether it be its characters, atmosphere, or even its soundtrack, just gives it way more personality than some Grand Theft Autos. It never feels like a chore to play, with more varied missions that keep it interesting long after you'd usually get bored with a GTA campaign. When I saw it on the Summer Sale, I got without hesitation and started my journey through Bullworth Academy for my 4th time. The only complaint I have with the game is that the towns outside of the school never feel as fleshed out or interesting. But that and minor glitches aside, Bully is a fenominal game. And if you have a controller nearby to use, Bully: Scholarship Edition is a fenominal port.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												A good, solid game with a lot of charm. However, just like it's protagonist, it's rough around the edges and lacks what is needed for it to be great. When people say it's kinda like GTA in school enviroment, they're right. It's kinda like GTA. Unlike GTA, you're somewhat limited by the school system and time, because you can only do certain things at certain time, but the time flies by quickly and so does the tempo of this game. You're constantly on the move, doing a lot of smaller missions and try to fit them to your daily routine, which is not a bad thing, but a lot of missions are really primitive, especially compared to GTA. Many of them are creative, so you won't be getting bored, I just wish we perhaps had less and more fleshed out ones. You can of course slow down, doing less every day and just fart around, but it can be frustrating, knowing you have to commit truancy to finish a mission, when you want to go to class so you can get a nice upgrade (passing at least some classes is adviced, others give you crap like different clothes you'll likely never wear out of embarrasement).Bully has a lot going for it, but it has some drawbacks, making it somewhat difficult to recommend to everyone. First off, the obvious - poor PC conversion. You will not have a good time playing this with keyboard and mouse. A gamepad is a must. Second, the controls are sometimes very loose and inprecise, plus the autoaiming system when you fight somebody is downright broken, on multiple occasions it targeted an ally, or target that was much further than the one I actually wanted to attack. Also, I really had an issue with a camera, not only it likes to fly around like crazy, but the default view is almost sitting on the ground, not like in any GTA, where it flies over your shoulder. Here, I found myself constantly battling against it.The game has a decent lenght, but it pales compared to GTA. It's by no means short game, but I couldn't help wishing for more - spending more time with certain characters, longer missions and better main story, which is rather weak to be honest, not that it's bad, there are many great moments, but it's somewhat overshadowed by smaller and isolated encounters with weird inhabitants of Bullworth. You meet a lot of hillarious characters once or twice, and then they just fade away, or maybe you'll bump into them randomly, and that's kinda it. Not that it's dissapointing, once again, I just wish there was more, because this settings has so much potential. The main protagonist is kinda underdeveloped, he doesn't have that much character going for and sometimes does questionable things without questioning them at all, when just few seconds before he was pretty vocal about it.With that out of the way, Bully is worth your time. For a great price, there is every school steteotype imaginable, it's all filled to the top with great humor. Dialogues are fantastic, characters are fantastic (although you spend way less time with those that are really interesting, and there is very little character development, again, probably due to the more arcady nature of the game), the atmosphere is fantastic and despite you being limited to much smaller area than San Andreas for example, it's packed with stuff to do. I've especially liked that weather changes as you go through whole year and so does appearance of everything. I don't think there are many games from school enviroment, but I'm willing to bet there aren't any that have open world and are this funny. It is a miracle that we even got this game, and even though it's flawed and lacking, it puts an evil grin on my face.// Also, outdoor graphics are strangely muddy and blurred, there is some rather unfortunate effect applied there, and it doesn't happen indoors. Because of that, when you first start the game, you'll immediatelly feel like something is wrong, and that perhaps you have a wrong resolution. No, it's the game, either a weird design decision, or another bug.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
												While this game is old and the graphics are dated, the story, voice acting, and gameplay are an absolute riot. The characters are colorful and the little quests you have to do are never too easy or too difficult. If it was re-released with a new, HD polish, I can only imagine how it would top the sales charts. The gamepad works fantastically with this game. Absolutely worth a purchase-- especially when it's on sale! Imagine GTA, except way less gritty, violent, and dark. Another major plus of this game is the progtagonist. He's extemely likable and honorable, but not in a goody-two-shoes kind of way. It's easy to connect with him as a character, which is important (given you play AS him). The school itself is the prison of legends, and it's really satisfying to screw it all up by egging your principals house while you monopolize all four factions in the little city.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												A small town GTA-like game about an increadibly aggressive but at the same time noble boy at the Bullworth Academy. It surely is not a perfect game, but still worth playing in my oppinion, because of its unique scenario and storyline. If you want to try it, pick it up at a sale, it is often available at very low prices.Overall the story was nice, very unrealistic at times, but still nice. It features some very odd humor and a highly stereotypical view at US school environments. The mission design seemed to me to be a lot easier on the player than the GTA 3 and IV series of games (which were frustratingly hard and unforgiving at times). I think of this as a mostly positive thing, but some missions like most of the races just felt a bit too easy. The game has five story chapters including a lot of separate missions and additionally has a bunch of minigames called classes which can be accessed at specific day times or are forced upon you if the school agents catch you while classes are running. Most of these classes were quite OK and revolve around pressing the right buttons when signalled or dragging icons to marked places. One of the classes on the other hand was so hard that I skipped it all along after three retries.The game was first released in 2006 and was ported to PC in 2008, a few months before GTA IV was released. The graphics level more resembles GTA San Andreas than GTA IV and looks quite ugly by 2013 standards. There are also quite a lot of rendering and texture glitches and a 30 frames per second limit in the PC version. The latter can be solved by a modified executable file (check the Steam guides) which works mostly fine but breaks one mission. Even if the PC port was overly hungry for resources (I do not know, but most Rockstar ports are) this didn't affect me much anymore because the game ran very smooth on the highest settings on hardware from 2013.I cannot state much about the keyboard/mouse control scheme, which other commentators stated to be horrific (which would resemble the situation of the GTA 3 and IV series ports) because I played the game with an Xbox 360 wireless controller through the PC adapter. Played with the controller the game's handling didn't feel so bad, but could have been done a bit better at times. The combat, even though there were quite a lot of moves to be acquired throughout the game, most of the times felt quite annoying. The vehicle mechanics like skateboard, bikes and go-carts didn't feel bad at all.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
Welcome to Bullworth Academy, an interesting place to say the least. You play as Jimmy Hopkins, a delinquent child on his last chance in an open world. As your progress through the game, you unlock access to more parts of the world, which contains a vast area to explore. This game is a classic, and is just as fun today as it was 10 years ago.Pros:+Visuals have aged very well for a 10 year old game+The gameplay is smooth, with the encounter of a bug being very rare+Very playable, third time playing this game from start to finish and was still enjoyable+Open world full of quirks to explore+Characters fit to their groups seamlessly, making it seem very close to a real school experience+Wide variety of characters with each dialogue fitting in almost naturally +Each environment is carefully designed and makes the setting seem almost realCons:-Main story is generally short, possibly beatable in one long sitting-Sounds sometimes seem out of place, removing a little from the immersion -Limited to a certain playstyle, most choices are made for youOverall this game is a classic, and I highly reccomend it. Well worth full price.9/10

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												     Probably Rockstar's best game. There isn't anything that really needs to be said about this game other than that it's just game, no stupid tutorials, no unnecessary features, it is just done well with just the right amount of stuff. Not only that, it follows a really unique gameplay style (more kid friendly than their edgy Manhunt too) which is pretty fun to play, a nice story that actually shows how bad bullying is and shows Jimmy being rewarded for being a "good" character, and a great port to the PC. This doesn't really need to be mentioned, but there isn't any problem with controls, or any bugs, or any problems at all, it does every really well and it feels really nice on PC. If you need me to describe what makes this game so good I will easily describe what makes this game so good (since there is a lot).This game's story is just great. There is so much to it and it is so great. It's all about characterization, but still manages to focus on gameplay and problems in the game world. Each chapter shows you gaining the respect of each clique, while showing you not only what their stereotypical clique is, but what each character there is like, which can be pretty funny, or if not, interesting to listen to. I don't think there is any part where I was really bored, which is great. There are also side missions which typically are teachers asking you to do things for them, and are actually somewhat linear themselves. These missions really give you an idea of what the people are like in this game in the background, and gives you a whole world to immerse yourself in. It really does well with the immersion, especially with just how humorous the world is (it's showing that the whole world is almost literally out to get him, and that not only are the teachers idiots, drunks, or evil, but the kids are essentially stereotypes who aren't interesting, but interesting at the same time, something you have to love about this game). Overall, it's really a great experience that you'd have to see for yourself on why it's so great.The gameplay style is pretty interesting too since you play as a 15 year old in a really bad school and neighborhood. There isn't any killing or weapons, and because of that, it focuses more on melee combat and combos, and special stuff like eggs and stink bombs. Other than the combat, there are still stores and an open world like GTA, just a lot smaller, so you focus more on using the map to your advantage and experiencing the importance of each area. Also, there are fun minigames like the Challenges for save points and the Carnival, which both reward you with cool stuff. If nothing else, it's a pretty worthwhile experience just because it's something new, but it's a lot more than that.Overall, this game is a lot of fun and definitely worth paying even full price for. You'll definitely get your money out of this and more. I really can't describe anything more than that so for the best idea of what this game is about you'll have to play it.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												I am so ecstatic that this game runs properly on my PC; I was incredibly intimidated by all of the Negative reviews claiming it's broken. Perhaps it's because my PC is an outdated laptop...Others have said it, so I'll be brief: From the developer, you already know that it's an open-world sandbox. Instead of a gangster/criminal/cowboy, you play as an outlaw/thug/ne'er-do-well in a preparatory school. The game is truly like The Warriors + GTA: 3/Vice City/SAndreas, in the mechanics; The game is truly unique otherwise.One of the things that impressed me most about Bully is how they were creative in rewarding players for going to class:Do well in English/Art (I forget which) to learn social skills (so much making-out with chicks).Do well in Chemistry to learn how to make Firecrackers and so forth.Do well in Gym to learn more advanced fighting techniques (or find scrap around the school and give it to the hobo that lives on the grounds, to learn "super-classified" fighting techniques).Etc., etc..P.S.: No Rockstar Social Club!EDIT: Huhhhhh, yet again, a port from an old♥♥♥♥♥game is (")shoddy("). TO BE SURE, with all of these ports - I am soooo glad to have them in my Library! Classics are classic. So any sort of complaining about the quality of the ports; I only do so to warn others (again, though, the majority (if not the enirety) of the Negative reviews are only Negative because "the game is broke,"). With Bully, the issues are: Sometimes while running, if you try and look around with the Right Stick, it is unresponsive or doesn't work as intended. Also, sometimes the picture tears and cutscenes get bogged down. These problems have not hampered me in any way, though.As for the game itself, I forgot just how unrelenting the Faculty is in combatting Truancy. Far too often, they will interrupt you while on a Mission because, with the way Time works, there is little breathing room. I'm pretty sure that when I played Bully originally, I just buckled down and went to all my Classes before attempting too many Missions. I enjoy this game, thoroughly; The persistent Prefects only add to the immersion.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												The Nerd Challenge:Day 1 - I check out the Nerd Challenge. I have to beat the ConSumo score of 1,010. Seems pretty easy. I get to 234 lb., and die.Day 2 - Still, nothing too hard. I can beat it. I have lots of money to spend on this game, anyway.Day 3 - Starting to get a little mad here. I've tried at least 20 times now, and gotten as close as 800 lb..Day 4 - Sumo pushed me into a blowfish. Getting a little angry now.Day 7 - I keep trying and trying, but it's those stupid blowfish.Day 12 - Should I beat up the Nerds? Is this even worth it? I've tried over 50 times now...Day 21 - The Nerd Challenge still sits there. It taunts me.Day 35 - All the Nerds are gone. Technically, I can take the place, but Fatty's high score still sits there.Day 48 - The arcade machine is starting to make a grinding noise. I'm sure it's okay.Day 63 - Pretty sure somone robbed the joke shop upstairs. Why? I don't care. I must beat the high score. I must beat the Nerd Challenge.Day 89 - I've ran out of food down here, in the basement of the joke shop. Gone without food for nearly 10 days now. I refuse to go up. I must complete the Nerd Challenge.Day 99 - I think I've been considered missing. Even dead. Still haven't beat the high score.Day 146 - 999 lb. Then a blowfish got me. They must die.Day 234 - People are knocking on the locked door now. I can't let them break my concentration.Day 304 - The arcade machine stopped working completely. I can't open the door. I'm stuck down here. I've been eating rats that come down here. I think I've ran out of rats.Day 4,321 - I got the acrade machine working again. I beat the Nerd Challenge. Apparently there was a nuclear apocalypse while I was out there. Oh, well.10/10 best Rockstar game.

With Bully, the issues are: Sometimes while running, if you try and look around with the Right Stick, it is unresponsive or doesn't work as intended. Also, sometimes the picture tears and cutscenes get bogged down. These problems have not hampered me in any way, though.As for the game itself, I forgot just how unrelenting the Faculty is in combatting Truancy. Far too often, they will interrupt you while on a Mission because, with the way Time works, there is little breathing room. I'm pretty sure that when I played Bully originally, I just buckled down and went to all my Classes before attempting too many Missions. I enjoy this game, thoroughly; The persistent Prefects only add to the immersion.

												The Nerd Challenge:Day 1 - I check out the Nerd Challenge. I have to beat the ConSumo score of 1,010. Seems pretty easy. I get to 234 lb., and die.Day 2 - Still, nothing too hard. I can beat it. I have lots of money to spend on this game, anyway.Day 3 - Starting to get a little mad here. I've tried at least 20 times now, and gotten as close as 800 lb..Day 4 - Sumo pushed me into a blowfish. Getting a little angry now.Day 7 - I keep trying and trying, but it's those stupid blowfish.Day 12 - Should I beat up the Nerds? Is this even worth it? I've tried over 50 times now...Day 21 - The Nerd Challenge still sits there. It taunts me.Day 35 - All the Nerds are gone. Technically, I can take the place, but Fatty's high score still sits there.Day 48 - The arcade machine is starting to make a grinding noise. I'm sure it's okay.Day 63 - Pretty sure somone robbed the joke shop upstairs. Why? I don't care. I must beat the high score. I must beat the Nerd Challenge.Day 89 - I've ran out of food down here, in the basement of the joke shop. Gone without food for nearly 10 days now. I refuse to go up. I must complete the Nerd Challenge.Day 99 - I think I've been considered missing. Even dead. Still haven't beat the high score.Day 146 - 999 lb. Then a blowfish got me. They must die.Day 234 - People are knocking on the locked door now. I can't let them break my concentration.Day 304 - The arcade machine stopped working completely. I can't open the door. I'm stuck down here. I've been eating rats that come down here. I think I've ran out of rats.Day 4,321 - I got the acrade machine working again. I beat the Nerd Challenge. Apparently there was a nuclear apocalypse while I was out there. Oh, well.10/10 best Rockstar game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												This was a fantastic game back in the day of the PS2 era, still is to be honest. It's great when Rock star bring their games to pc, *Cough* Red Dead Redemption *Cough*.So with Bully being developed by beloved RockStar, it was designed from the same vein as GTA...but with kids...and no guns...or killing. Not necessary a major drag, you just get to run around with a super powered slingshot, stink bombs and fire crackers to really annoy people.The game is based around a 15 year kid called Jimmy Hopkins, who is transferred to a boarding school because his mum wanted to go on a 12+ month holiday. Lucky her, eh? So you're the new kid, and you need to work your way up the ranks to be at the top of the school. So naturally no one respects or fears you to start with, even the nerds of the school. So you do the usual mission progression and go through the chapters, which are pretty much like school terms, and you work for different school groups to gain their respect and trust.That's pretty much the jist of the game, other than that it's got you're typical collectables hunt, garage full of vehicles (in this case it's push bikes), shops selling you goods to help you with your carnage, and mini games to help you earn extra cash / abilities.The mini games are kinda fun and can completed fairly quickly. You've got your class room mini games and your 'earn some do$h' mini games. The cash ones are typical teenager jobs, such as a paper route or mowing lawns. But with the class room mini games they help improve Jimmy's abilities, such as chemistry lessons help buff up your chemistry set to create more useful and powerful prank tools. Auto shop gives you better push bikes, English helps you pick up the ladies ;D and so on. The class room mini games can essentially be completed in the first chapter, so no more lessons for the whole year! If only...*Sigh*Quite a lengthy game, if you go for 100% completion. The story is a bit meh and generic, like it's been done in a way before in previous RockStar game. Not going to give too many spoilers now! You'll just have to play and find out ;)  Then again, I could be completely getting one of the GTA games plots all wrong in my head, I hope not.But there are some good moments in the story with memorable, and stereo typical, characters you expect from a US school. Can't say I can really relate to be honest, British high school life is waaaaaaaay different. Thanks for butchering the spirit of The Inbetweeners, USA...An annoying factor to the game is the restriction at night where you can't be out of your dorm past 8 pm, other wise you get chased by the never sleeping prefects and police. If you're out after 2 or 3 am, you automatically get knocked out and appear in your dorm for 8 am. So you can't be a crazy kid and never sleep, ever.I do have to you warn you though, since this was a console port to the PC the controls aren't 100% perfect. So I recommend playing with a controller. Not the keyboard & Mouse!Over all the game isn't too bad, defiantly worth picking up if you have nostalgic feelings towards this game. I know I did, and didn't regret it! :DIn conclusion:  Fairly decent graphics from the PS2 era.  Good story, the game is quite lengthy if you also do the side content.  Excellent alternative to the GTA series, if you're looking for a less violent game.  Plenty of side content to keep a completionist busy for a few hours.  Fun character clothing customising. Make Jimmy look like a right ponce.  Fairly big open world.  Irritating in game hours, in which you have only so many to do stuff in.  Poor port to PC, use a game pad rather than a keyboard & mouse.7 / 10 Get the Go-Kart asap, other wise you won't be able to run the old ladies over fast enough before they dive out of the way.

number of helpful: 8 of 16 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												NB: I've played more than the 0.2 hours shown because I had to download a patched .exe from the internet.It seems like a great game but I just can't recommend it on the PC. It's a poor console port with a 30fps lock and very few graphics options. The game will run fine, but it seems that on modern OSs it just isn't worth it. This game crashes constantly on modern systems with more than 2GB RAM (even the patched version).  The fact that there are no autosaves or checkpoints means that the game is pretty much unplayable, since every time you complete something the game crashes and all your progress is reset. Aside from that, the keyboard and mouse controls are absolutely abysmal, some of the worst I've seen on PC. If you are confident in buying this game, make sure you have a controller available. I read some reviews telling me to do this, and didn't heed them. Seriously, unless you have a controller you are absolutely wasting your time.In summary, a good game that's absolutely unplayable without a controller and incredibly restricted by bad porting and game instability.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												Rockstar's known for going a little overboard on the comments from the random passers-by in their games, but this takes that to ridiculous levels. The comments are non-stop and take away any bit of pleasure I may have had with the game. "Stick it in your ear" is not something anyone should be forced to listen to every 20 seconds, I don't care what your crime is; well, that is, unless your crime is creating the game "Bully". I found myself trying to dodge pedestrians just to save my ears. My goal became to finish missions from the shadows with as little interaction with the game's population as possible.At that point, I found little to no pleasure in playing through the B-movie grade storyline with less than stellar voice acting. Sure, I could have turned the voice volume all the way down, but I would have lost out on the cut scenes too. I'm not saying that's anything to be missed, but, frankly, the game isn't challenging enough to make me want to play it without hearing the cut scenes as well. This review would have gone much better if the developers had added an option to decrease the amount of banter.UPDATE-------------Since I'm obviously in the minority with my negative review, I decided to take a look at the others. I noticed a lot of folks complaining of crashes on Windows 10. I'm playing the game on Windows 10 and was able to play it just fine. The game did crash once when I was attempting to set my resolution, but, outside of that, it ran like a champ. I would disregard the Windows 10 woes. If that was an actual issue, it seems to have been taken care of.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												Performance wise it did crash 2-3 times, but overall ran really smoothly for such an "old-ish" ps2 game, for me personally, it seemed a really alright port. The controls IMO were quite easy to get accustomed to if you edited them to your liking, played it with keyboard and mouse and persoanlly loved the experience.The world is filled with small interactions and stuff that'll make your stance between missions enjoyable and not make you feel like you are running around in circles in an open world made just for the sake of padding hours in it. It has a great variety of really chrming "weapons" that fit completly with the school setting. They managed to make classes incredibly fun, which it's a merit on it's own, from dissecting frogs to cranking a bike the enjoyment of them is quite great, although some do get a little bit tedious over time. Got almost all the classes completed in a single playthrough, but you'll miss a few unless you keep playing after endgame.Customization is alright, but if you change hairstyles you change jimmy's whole face quality/shading/structure which is kinda weird but passable considering the age of the game. Clothes are pretty varied and fun. Story and characters are cliché to a humorous extent, but it's what gives it al lot of the charm this game has. The dialogue is hilarious in most of the cases, mocking everything high school represents and every person you can find in one in a sometimes subtle and sometimes in your face humor that rarely fails to deliver chcukles. Even with all the hilarious, this game does not fail to deliver a great story that let's you taste progression in every part of it. The game did get incredibly easy midway through tho, but was still fun just over how much you can ♥♥♥♥ around the school, the city and the amusment park.Side activities pop up while riding your bike/skateboard/running around town and sometimes on the map if they are "story-ish" related, but the non story or "story-ish" ones get a little bit repetitive and you'll most likely end up not caring about them because you'll be bathing in money in no time even without doing them.Got 22 hours in it while doing all of the sidequests but 2, almost all the classes, and ♥♥♥♥ing around town very little, if you like collectibles and stuff it will take you quite a while more as there are 2 types of collectibles that are quite large in number. So you'll definetely get a bang for your buck with this game.Definitely my favorite rockstar game, couldn't recommend it enough!

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												I've enjoyed Rockstar Games' 'Grand Theft Auto' series ever since the release of 'Grand Theft Auto: Vice City'. I thought they did a great job technically with their game engines and stylistically with the visual designs. Plus, 'Grand Theft Auto' games are great satire of the crime film/game genre and of contemporary society for the most part. While aware of the negative impact the games can have on society and the younger generation of gamers, I still defend the merits of 'Grand Theft Auto' games.I was pretty stoked when I first read about 'Bully' back in 2005/2006, but was disappointed that the first iteration would not come to the PC platform. About a decade later, I finally got my hands on the remastered version of the game, thinking that Rockstar had injected similar type of technical and stylistic mastery, and social acuity into crafting this game as they did with 'Grand Theft Auto'. Was I wrong. True, in the year 2015, the game engine that runs 'Bully' will definitely show its age; I can accept that. However, 'Bully: Scholarship Edition' looks and sounds very uneven in spite of the remastering. The keyboard and mouse controls for the PC also feel unoptimized.The truth is, I just can't recommend 'Bully: Scholarship Edition'. It simply lacks the energy, fire and humour that I enjoy in 'Grand Theft Auto' games. The setting of Bullworth Academy, while well-designed, just doesn't seem to allow for much exploration. It feels too confined and claustrophobic even when compared to 'Grand Theft Auto: Vice City', which was released in 2002. Most importantly, 'Bully' doesn't play or feel like a satire. It is pretty much a straight-up (private) school simulator full of cliques and stereotypes with uninspired early missions.While you may approach 'Bully' and complete missions with good intentions, and that your character implicitly dislikes being bullied, you ironically need to be a bully to accomplish your goals. The unsatirical tone of 'Bully' actually makes me feel horrible for my heinous actions in the game. While I can find some reason to justify my undertaking of violent acts in 'Grand Theft Auto', I find my actions and bullying in 'Bully' to be distasteful.In the end, I guess where 'Bully' fails is that it is too real. Whereas the action sequences, violence and set pieces in 'Grand Theft Auto' were designed to be cinematic, grandiose and hyperbolic -- making the games rather hyper-realistic, all the bullying and hijinx in 'Bully' are mostly possible and hit too close to home for comfort. Given the well documented negative impacts of bullying on people of all ages, I cannot in good conscience recommend 'Bully: Scholarship Edition'.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2016
												I played Bully so much on my PS2 when I was young and never had the chance to finish it and get the 100%, and I did all this on the Steam version. It's surely my favorite Rockstar game.-The story is very good, not too complex or outstanding, but it's very good.-The map is not too large, it's even kinda small if compared to other Rockstar titles, but you have anough stuff to do in it, so that's not such a big problem.-The missions are fun, really, really fun.-Side missions are as much fun and entertaining.-Lots of secrets to unlock.-It's addictive and fun to play the whole game, but sometimes it can get a bit repetitive, so you need to take a break when that happens, and come back after some time.-There are bugs, but they never really interfered in my experience, except the people walking around and their sounds being heard from the other side of the map.Also, if you have that bug when you start the game and everything disappear, you can fix this with a patch (just Google search "bully bug fix" and you'll probably find it somewhere).

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												Pros: Good conceptCons: Everything else, specifically the game content and the apalling interfaceThis is a very poor quality port. I haven't played it on a console, but it's obvious that it's not a PC game. To start with, the mouse control is atrociously bad. I can't see where I'm going and I needed to get a trackpad just to pick locks. The menu interfaces are diabolical: you have to use left shift control and space to select things that a mouse could click just as easily. The fight controls are similarly awful and hard to get the hang of. A mouse click would do the same job as holding r and left shift. Sprinting is a waste of effort too. Who wants to quickly tap shift?On to the game itself. The "missions" I've completed so far are so interesting that I want to stick my head in an oven. I had to speak to the headmaster, get some chocolates for a butch neurotic lesbian and walk to two classes. Oh, and then I had to put someone in a bin after chasing them for a few minutes. It's so unengaging I'd rather organise my desktop icons.For a game released in 2008, I can't help thinking that the graphics are a bit substandard too, but that's not really important. The glitchy sound is also very annoying. Oh, and I have to walk to some irrelevant room just to save. That would have been alright if this game was fun like Vice City, but it wasn't fun at all. The walks to the save room just gave me time to contemplate how♥♥♥♥♥♥it was.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												One of the unsung gems of Rockstar, Bully can be aptly described as "GTA for kids," but yet so much more. Don't let that tagline fool you, Bully is nearly as good as, if not better, than its M-Rated cousin, and deserves the cult following. Its missions are high in number but short and sweet, and it's easy to wreak havoc in the schoolyards witout a shred of guilt. More importanty, Jimmy Hopkins is a genuinely likeable character, which is saying a lot considering he's the poster boy for an angsty teenager. One of the better protagonists crafted by Rockstar by far, and simultaneously allow players to cause chaos at Bullworth without the cognitive dissonance and easily slip back into the role of a hero when the story calls for it.It would be wise, however, to skip out on the PC version, which is a lousy port, and go straight for the console versions, either for the Wii or the 360's HD edition.But if you want a short-but-sweet "Steam style" review, here's one!I said "hi" to a nerd. He tried to punch me in return. A prefect came and kicked his♥♥♥♥♥for me. 10/10.

In Bully you have to beat all the different groups and then make them your allies (or your enemies). Then once you have all of them on your side so they dont fight you everytime they see you, you have to surprisingly save the school. The different groups include the backstabbing nerds, the narcissist greasers, and the dumb but strong jocks.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												I am very conflicted about what to say. Bully is and always has been my favourite Rockstar game, let alone it being one of my favourite games. Its small and tight focus might seem like a downside but it results in a world more believable and memorable than any other Rockstar game, and all world evolves as you progress through the story with changing seasons and different decorations.That being said, the PC port is even bad by Rockstar standards and this is one of the worst modern ports ever and it's clearly never being fixed. The keyboard and mouse controls are awkward but playable if you don't have a controller, just rebind everything first because the defaults are awful. Some classes are way tougher than they should be on PC and even when they're not they're stuck with awful controls (left shift and right shift for music class!?!?!?), also I had glitches and bugs when I played on Windows 8 but this happened a lot more on Windows 10. Just be warned. Despite all the issues with this incredibly bad port, the game is still Bully and it's still good. If you can look passed it being an awful port then get this. However I strongly recommend playing Bully on Xbox 360 or PS3 unless you're really into the Bully modding scene. Excluding mods which aren't even that amazing, there is no benefit to playing on PC over the consoles that have the Scholarship Edition.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												This is a great blast from the past. Have you ever been bullied. Yes:well this is your chance to fight back! No, I bullied people: Well great uoull fit right in.Pros: Give wedgies, throw people in lockers, skip class, start fights, run from the cops, ride a ferris wheel, destroy gnomes for a carnie, and throwsnowballs at cars, this games great. It has the factions that dominate the schoolgrounds(before the emo/hipster/swag phase) such as the Jocks, Nerds, Bullies, Outcasts, and Greasers(yeah Greasers, bring the spud cannon). You dont have the largest aresnal in a game, but your in school, start off with a slingshot, get a skateboard, build your bicycle, make friends(advance in story) to get more weapons. Some weapons can be learned in class such as the stink bombs and firework launcher.Cons: The games dated, but not terribly. Think of going back to GTA:SA with a Vice city sized map( I guess), no lethal guns, only forms of are your always handy skatebord, and bicycles,no strippers.If you like what Rockstar puts out, but want less "adult content" then this is the game for you.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												I am very conflicted about what to say. Bully is and always has been my favourite Rockstar game, let alone it being one of my favourite games. Its small and tight focus might seem like a downside but it results in a world more believable and memorable than any other Rockstar game, and all world evolves as you progress through the story with changing seasons and different decorations.That being said, the PC port is even bad by Rockstar standards and this is one of the worst modern ports ever and it's clearly never being fixed. The keyboard and mouse controls are awkward but playable if you don't have a controller, just rebind everything first because the defaults are awful. Some classes are way tougher than they should be on PC and even when they're not they're stuck with awful controls (left shift and right shift for music class!?!?!?), also I had glitches and bugs when I played on Windows 8 but this happened a lot more on Windows 10. Just be warned. Despite all the issues with this incredibly bad port, the game is still Bully and it's still good. If you can look passed it being an awful port then get this. However I strongly recommend playing Bully on Xbox 360 or PS3 unless you're really into the Bully modding scene. Excluding mods which aren't even that amazing, there is no benefit to playing on PC over the consoles that have the Scholarship Edition.

												Don't get mistaken by my playtime, i pirated this then i bought it since the devs deserve it.Game is better than some GTA titles, it really puts you in shoes of ♥♥♥♥boy called Jimmy Hopkins witch got expelled from 7 schools, his mother got married 5 times (GG mom) so basically his life is a mess. He mets a dude called Garry and they become best of friends, but Garry wants to run the school and Jimmy wants to stop bullying little did Jimmy know, Gary is working behind his back and puts him in a "gladiator" cage to fight.*Game Mechanics*Game has a nice fighting system witch forces you to do combos for maximum damage (and some OP nut shots),If you want to get max health you have to seduce girls with gifts so they kiss youThere is respect bar of eatch faction, the lower respect is the more chance is that they will attack you on sightAfter you finish the game you will most likely have some stuff to complete since you have to collet 75 rubber bands, 40 G&G Cards, destroy 25 gnomes, 20 tombstones, 30 (i think) pumpkins etc.8.5/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 29, 2015
												Oh Rockstar, why do you do this to us..Within roughly two hours of playing, i've experienced 3 crashes. Luckily I had saved prior but I did experience one during a mission. One when picking up a book from the ground while outside a mission, and one while attempting to give a girl flowers. It's clear the game still has issues from when it was ported. Awkward controls make it evident and the 30fps cap was quite stupid..However... After playing this game on PS2, Xbox360, and even Wii- I have to say it's worth putting up with all its buggy nature simpily to enjoy what is arguablly one of Rockstars most under-rated titles. The music is great, gameplay is solid, and although the PC version isint as polished as the console counterparts, it works and if you can get past a few annoying crashes (also ensure you install the 60fps fix)- you'll have a pretty awesome game at your finger tips.NOTE: The game is great but don't spend $15 on it. I personally got it from GamersGate for $3 but seen it on sale directly on steam for like $5 quite often. The buggy nature is not worth Steam's indicated retail price; however, it is surely is worth $3-5 on sale.

Get to live the moments I missed in my own time in high school, like kissing all the girls XDThere's a vast array of missions you can do as well as running errands for some quick cash. It's a great open world game. Story so far seems pretty good too. I have had a few issues with the game however. There are some random lags I get as well as the mouse not working too well. Which can be annoying depending on the mission (ie aiming in first person, sometimes the mouse will jump past the target making me have to restart) as well as having experienced a never ending loop of the load screen and characters freezing during animations, forcing a game restart. The last 2 examples have only happened to me once each, so it seems to be a rare event, but thought I should mention it.With that said, if you save often, it's not a game breaking problem and I've really enjoyed this game.

content:
Posted: February 25
												This is an incredible game, everything ranging from the story, the characters, the gameplay, everything just feels right, as if in very clean, Bully is a very cleanly design game, amazing.With that being said tho, the actual port for this game it's terrible, terrible as in the game crashes after some time playing making you loose hours and hours of progress, this game like plenty of other Rockstar games has a saving system that requires you to be in an specific place in the game.Forcing me to retry hours upon hours of mission time that i've already completed it's an incredible way to make me forget about your game.Which is a shame, because as I said, the game, at its core, it's amazing, it's a wonderful experience for plenty of different reasons.I just wished Rockstar had embraced their new mentality of actually dedicating time and effort in their pc ports, when this game was released for pc Rockstar still thought having games running with limited options, 30 fps locks, and frequent crashes, was a fine thing to do.For games like this one that are games clearly made with effort, and passion, it's kinda sad to see them getting ditched and frown upon pc players, simply because Rockstar decided not to dedicate enough time to the pc port.This is one of those rare cases in which I would also not recommend you to try it even after thinking there might be fixes for this issues, there IS a fix for the game running at 30fps, there is however not a fix for the constant crashes that simply KILL the game for me, and plenty of other different people, if only there were some type of autosaving, or quicksaving feature, this would still be a problem, but it wouldn't be such a serious one at that, sadly tho, with this game there's no such thing, and as end result as amazing as the game is, as incredibly as my desire to recommend it stands in its own for what the concept behind the game holds, and is, I cannot recommend this game for pc, it just doesn't make sense in the least.Sorry, but this game deserves better, and your consumers as well Rockstar.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
												Having gotten this game back in Christmas 2007, I was young (10) and I fell in the love with the game. I loved the music, the humour, the characters, the brilliant attention to detail and most of all... the replay value. I have re-played and completed this game over Twenty-Seven times! Twenty--Seven... when have you ever loved a game sooooo much you played it Twenty-Seven times to the end? The fact is this is the perfect game. Perfect setting, perfect characters and an insane amount of fun! This game will never leave my mind, and I'm STILL waiting for a sequel. RockStar surprise us. Bring us Bully 2 and make it good. It will be hard to recapture the beatuy that is Canis Canem Edit, but if anyone can do it.. its RockStar.

Posted: July 19, 2014
												Pros:- Pretty much a soft-core version of GTA.- A lot of NPC's, each with different ( and funny ) dialogue.- Made by Rockstar.- Six different cliques, all unique, including Nerds, Jocks, Preppies, Bullies, Greasers, and Townies.- You can attend classes ( which are pretty fun minigames which you can unlock extra items from )- Instead of guns, you get makeshift weapons like fire-crackers, stink bombs, a slingshot, and even rotten eggs.- You can beat up old ladies.- Completely non-linear.- You can save people from the bullies, or even bully them yourself.- Instead of stealing cars, you can steal bikes, and scooters.Cons: - For a game made in 2008, the graphics don't seem that up-to-dateRating: 10/10Don't think, just buy this game! c:
